thread.title: Health care bill clears final hurdle before vote | New York Post
thread.title_full: Health care bill clears final hurdle before vote | New York Post

author: Marisa Schultz
title: Health care bill clears final hurdle before vote | New York Post

organizations.name: new york post the house rules committee

text:
The House Rules Committee voted Friday to send the Republicans’ new health care bill to the full House for debate and a final vote later in the day.
The committee voted 9-3 to move the bill and set up the parameters for the debate and subsequent vote, which top Republicans said was still too close to call.
The debate will be conducted under what is called a closed rule, which means that members can’t offer amendments on the floor.
Meanwhile, President Trump told lawmakers who oppose abortion that a vote against the health care bill would favor Planned Parenthood.
“The irony is that the Freedom Caucus, which is very pro-life and against Planned Parenthood, allows P.P. to continue if they stop this plan!” he wrote on Twitter.
In a bid to coax support from conservatives, House leaders proposed a fresh amendment repealing Obamacare’s requirement that insurers cover 10 specified services like maternity care, addiction treatment and mental health care.
Conservatives have demanded the removal of those and other conditions the law imposes on insurers, arguing they drive up premiums.
The president met with members of the Freedom Caucus Thursday in an effort to win them over.
But the vote was postponed after administration officials couldn’t muster the minimum votes needed.
Early Friday, after a ceremony in which he signed off on the Keystone pipeline deal, the president at first ignored questions from reporters about the vote but eventually answered, “we’ll have to see what happens,” the same phrase he used twice on Thursday.
Trump also answered “yes” when asked if House Speaker Paul Ryan should keep his job if the vote failed.
The Congressional Budget Office issued an updated score for the bill on Thursday, saying that the deficit reduction dropped to $150 billion over 10 years from the earlier projection of $337 billion because of the cost of amendments added since it issued its first score.
The CBO said 24 million people will lose insurance by 2026 under Trump’s bill.
